newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Ecuador welcomes WTO banana ruling.
newsitem.headline: Ecuador welcomes WTO banana ruling.

text.p: Ecuador, the world's biggest banana exporter, welcomed on Friday a World Trade Organisation final ruling that European Union banana import rules were unfair.
The WTO report, which was released confidentially three weeks ago to the governments involved, found that Europe's banana import regime violated WTO rules on 16 counts.

"We have been badly hurt by the EU banana regime over the past four years transferring profits to powerful multinationals, not to ACP (African, Caribbean and Pacific) producers," Alfredo Pinoargote, Ecuador's ambassador to the EU, said in a statement.
Ecuador's banana industry is entirely in local, private hands and some 10 percent of the population depends on banana imports for a living, he added.

Pinoargote said the EU banana import licensing system flouted world trade rules because it allocated 30 percent of a special tariff quota to operators with no history of importing Latin American bananas.
"Trading rights over Ecuadorian bananas have been arbitrarily transferred to a select number of EU and multinational companies," he said.
Ecuador stressed that its complaint was against the licence allocation scheme and not against trade preferences granted to ACP bananas under the Lome convention.
The WTO ruling is a blow for several small Caribbean nations that depend on preferential exports of bananas to keep their local economies afloat.
The EU, which may appeal against the ruling, has warned that ending the preferences risked causing economic and social unrest in Caribbean countries.
